title: A jungler's perspective: How I picture the S5 Jungle developement went
body:
"So, J4 and Lee are completely dominating the meta, AGAIN. Maybe it would be healthy if we slightly ner..."
"Nononononono, nerf Smite."
"But the other junglers?"
"Who cares."

"Boss, the Smite nerfs didn't help! Maybe we really should nerf J4 and Le......"
"Nonononono! Make jungle items more expensive"
"But the othe..."
"I SAID MAKE THEM MORE EXPENSIVE!"
"Aye, chief."

"Uhm, Boss? J4 and Lee are still dominating the meta.."
"How can this be? We've done such a good job patching the jungle!"
"Maybe we should simply nerf J4 and L.."
"Nonononono, I  got it! We simply nerf the jungle items AGAIN!"
"But, Sir we've already tried tha..."
"YOU HEARD WHAT I SAID!"
"Aye, chief."

"Boss, I'm sorry to disturb you again - but Lee and j4 are STILL dominating the meta."
"Don't annoy me with such oddments. Buff the jungle creeps. Pronto!"
"B....b...but Chief - we've already made viable jungling near impossible for 3/4 of S4s champion roster!"
"Does Lee still work?"
"Yes, but him dominating the meta is why we initiallly.."
"I don't get your problem! Jungling is obviously working! Stop complaining already!"
"Aye chief..."

-----------------


Even though I use Lee as my primary "example", this is not meant to be a direct complaint about him (even though I'ld say that he lacks a clear weakness).

It's more about how the jungle has developed and that it seems viabilty hasn't taken into account the average jungle champion, but only the top notch picks - with the result of driving a lot of champion out of the jungle while cementing the top notch junglers as such (instead of attempting to equalize the capability to jungle across a more varied champion roster).

I want to see a base damage nerf on Lee actually go through. Lee Sin **needs** this kind of nerf for all the utility and mobility he has on low cooldowns—and with an energy bar, no less.

They did exactly this to Rek'Sai, and right now she has to prioritize damage if she wants to actually deal damage. This means she's squishy for the majority of the match. She doesn't have Lee's constant mobility threat, his CC, or his execute. For her melee-range true damage; her melee-range knockup; her visible, destructible tunnels; and the damage-less global ult that's completely reliant on said tunnels, she has virtually no base damage, and she's hilariously kitable.

Prey Seeker doesn't even have a slow. Lee has an AoE slow.

Unburrow is only for the knockup, *requires* you to be in the danger zone, and it only works once on a unit every ten seconds. Lee Sin can Safeguard to safety immediately after going in. Rek'Sai can't tunnel out while unburrowed.

Dragon Kick has high base damage, a 200% bonus AD ratio, a knockback effect that *equally* damages everything that the target hits while in flight, and a 60 second cooldown at max rank without CDR. It is guaranteed to be up for every single teamfight, and then some.

Lee gets up to 25% free lifesteal and spellvamp. Rek'Sai's passive health recovery removes her ability to use her aforementioned melee-range true damage.

Rek'Sai is more balanced than Lee Sin—underpowered, even—and it really shows just how heavily and unhealthily Lee Sin is favored by Riot that they outright refuse to balance him. "Community outcry" is an overly shitty excuse; it's never stopped them before, so why only for Lee Sin?

**I'm sick and tired of this Lee Circle-jerk.**

Yes, Lee is strong, yes he has a lot of options and potential built into his kit. Yes he can be frustrating to play against at times. Is he overpowered broken freelo? No. Not in casual play and not in competitive play.

Well I'm not sure if you mean by the community's standards or by Riot's standards. In either case I don't think this is true. I doubt that Riot bases their entire balance scheme around 1 champion. Although it might be amusing for us to think so.

> Riot seems to forget that he has great clearspeed and sustain while having great ganks

They didn't. Lee (and other early-game pressure junglers like Elise, Evelyn, and Kha'zix) are largely the reason why the Jungle monsters were made to be harder to clear. So that champions couldn't just itemize damage, full-clear the jungle, and gank without any trade-offs. Now those trade-offs do exist! I think you overestimate Lee's "clearspeed and sustain." His clear is decent, but his sustain is garbage. A 40 damage shield and 5% life-steal and spell-vamp for 4 seconds is barely noticeable. It eases up pretty quick into the mid-game, but Lee gets beaten up really hard by the jungle-monsters early on. Lee's early presence is nothing what is used to be. It is still relatively strong, yes, but not as strong as it once was.

> Many champions don't have half of that earlygame presence since they're much more lategame orientated

Well, that's sort of the point isn't it? Lee is made to be an early-game champ, and others are supposed to shine in the mid and late game. Is Lee's power relatively too strong early game compared to the late-game pay-off of other champions? Perhaps, but I don't think this is something that can't be fixed by turning a few nobs. Some other champions could use some light buffs, or the jungle could be changed in some small ways to benefit champions who don't itemize damage early. (EX. Tier 2/3 jungle item passive damage buffed so that defensive junglers can keep up in farm, while Junglers who itemize damage gain relatively little in terms of clear-speed).

The solution isn't in nerfing Lee Sin, but elsewhere. And even then, the problem is largely overstated.

> However Riot Balances the jungle for the earlygame, not the lategame.

I don't believe this is true. Riot has taken many anti-snowballing measures in Season 3 and Season 4, making the game overall less oriented towards the early-game. The game will likely always have a tendency to favor early-pressure champions however because gaining early leads are the best way to win games. I don't think Riot is focused on "balancing around the earlygame," just that the game in general favors early-game champions in its inherent design. Riot may have some work to do here, but again nerfing Lee Sin probably isn't the solution.

> His kit is so overloaded with everything, making him a universal pick that ruins diversity.

I'll start here. In competitive play, I completely agree with you. But he is only part of the champion pool that limits diversity in competitive picks overall. That's another pie altogether, but because I play casually, I'd prefer to turn the rest of this discussion towards that topic.

In casual play, I don't think Lee Sin is choking out diversity at all. In fact, I believe that just about any "traditional" jungler except maybe Evelyn can be played in SoloQ and can win games consistently if you play according to champion strengths. 

> What is Lee Sin's weakness

This is where I think a lot of people misinterpret Lee. I'll start with the obvious, but often overlooked change in Season 5.

1) Lee has a relatively difficult time staying healthy during his early-jungle clears. Thus he is has limited opportunities to use his strongest period of the game (early-game) effectively. This isn't season 4 where Lee could go and gank, and if he screwed up, could turn around and full-clear his jungle and try again. Now, if Lee ganks at inopportune times, or focuses on farming when he should be ganking, he will be punished. This trade-off actually exists now.

2) Lee lacks linear strengths. Yes, he has MANY options. He has a lot of tools at his disposal. However, it isn't always clear how he can combine these tools to make powerful plays. As such, it takes a lot of lot of experience on Lee's part to abuse his mechanics correctly. Players can easily play against Lee's most power/linear tools (IE, Insec Kick and Early Ganks) by either warding or grouping. In such circumstances, Lee is instantly pressured to become more creative with his mechanics to become useful. It may be hard to pin him down specifically, but does it really matter if you can turn around and kill the rest of his team after?

Lee is a jack-of-all-trades but master of none. He can do all things *well* but can't do any one-thing amazingly consistently.

To compare with other strong champions right now - Vi and Jarvan. Jarvan and Vi both have relatively safer and faster early clears (Both with arguably better neutral monster control and objective control as well). Moreover, their power is very straight-forward - dive into the enemy team and press all their buttons over the carry. They can rely on their tankiness and teamates to follow up on their initial burst of damage and lock-down. This linear power is extremely valuable because it means that people playing these champs can unlock their champion's potential MUCH more easily than Lee Sin players can.

So to conclude, Lee Sin doesn't *really* have clear weaknesses. Instead, his *weakness* persay is that he lacks a category at which he can decisively be better than other champions. As such, he relies on his ability to do all things *well enough* to win games. However, I can lock in J4, Vi, Pantheon, or Fiddlesticks, have a much clearer gameplan on how to win the game, and effectively abuse my strengths better than Lee Sin can abuse his.

I understand this may be confusing, but I hope it helps explain why I think Lee is over-hyped. Yes he can do a lot of things *well.* But he is always outclassed in every category by some other champion. As such, it is difficult for Lee Sin to correctly use his kit to make powerful plays in the same way that other champions can.
